trans-unit.source: Use SSH to connect to Linux virtual machines in Azure
trans-unit.target: Use SSH to connect to Linux virtual machines in Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to generate and use SSH keys with a Linux virtual machine on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to generate and use SSH keys with a Linux virtual machine on Azure.

trans-unit.source: How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure
trans-unit.target: How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure

trans-unit.source: The current version of the Azure Management Portal only accepts SSH public keys that are encapsulated in an X509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: The current version of the Azure Management Portal only accepts SSH public keys that are encapsulated in an X509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps below to generate and use SSH keys with Azure.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps below to generate and use SSH keys with Azure.

trans-unit.source: Generate Azure Compatible Keys in Linux
trans-unit.target: Generate Azure Compatible Keys in Linux

trans-unit.source: Install the openssl utility if needed:
trans-unit.target: Install the openssl utility if needed:

trans-unit.source: CentOS / Oracle Linux
trans-unit.target: CentOS / Oracle Linux

trans-unit.source: Ubuntu
trans-unit.target: Ubuntu

trans-unit.source: SLES & openSUSE
trans-unit.target: SLES & openSUSE

trans-unit.source: Use openssl to generate an X509 certificate with a 2048-bit RSA keypair.
trans-unit.target: Use openssl to generate an X509 certificate with a 2048-bit RSA keypair.

trans-unit.source: Please answer the few questions that the openssl prompts for (or you may leave them blank).
trans-unit.target: Please answer the few questions that the openssl prompts for (or you may leave them blank).

trans-unit.source: The content in these fields is not used by the platform:
trans-unit.target: The content in these fields is not used by the platform:

trans-unit.source: Change the permissions on the private key to secure it.
trans-unit.target: Change the permissions on the private key to secure it.

trans-unit.source: Upload the myCert.pem while creating the Linux virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Upload the myCert.pem while creating the Linux virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The provisioning process will automatically install the public key in this certificate into the authorized_keys file for the specified user in the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The provisioning process will automatically install the public key in this certificate into the authorized_keys file for the specified user in the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: If you are going to use the API directly, and not use the Management Portal, convert the myCert.pem to myCert.cer (DER encoded X509 certificate) using the following command:
trans-unit.target: If you are going to use the API directly, and not use the Management Portal, convert the myCert.pem to myCert.cer (DER encoded X509 certificate) using the following command:

trans-unit.source: Generate a Key from an Existing OpenSSH Compatible Key
trans-unit.target: Generate a Key from an Existing OpenSSH Compatible Key

trans-unit.source: The previous example describes how to create a new key for use with Azure. In some cases you may already have an existing OpenSSH compatible public & private key pair and wish to use the same keys with Azure.
trans-unit.target: The previous example describes how to create a new key for use with Azure. In some cases you may already have an existing OpenSSH compatible public & private key pair and wish to use the same keys with Azure.

trans-unit.source: OpenSSH private keys are directly readable by the openssl utility.
trans-unit.target: OpenSSH private keys are directly readable by the openssl utility.

trans-unit.source: The following command will take an existing SSH private key (id_rsa in the example below) and create the .pem public key that is needed for Azure:
trans-unit.target: The following command will take an existing SSH private key (id_rsa in the example below) and create the .pem public key that is needed for Azure:

trans-unit.source: The myCert.pem file is the public key that may then be used to provision a Linux virtual machine on Azure.
trans-unit.target: The myCert.pem file is the public key that may then be used to provision a Linux virtual machine on Azure.

trans-unit.source: During provisioning the .pem file will be translated into an openssh compatible public key and placed in ~/.ssh/authorized_keys.
trans-unit.target: During provisioning the .pem file will be translated into an openssh compatible public key and placed in ~/.ssh/authorized_keys.

trans-unit.source: Connect to an Azure Virtual Machine from Linux
trans-unit.target: Connect to an Azure Virtual Machine from Linux

trans-unit.source: In some cases the SSH endpoint for a Linux virtual machine may be configured for a port other then the default port 22.
trans-unit.target: In some cases the SSH endpoint for a Linux virtual machine may be configured for a port other then the default port 22.

trans-unit.source: You can find the correct port number on the Dashboard for the VM in the Management Portal (under "SSH Details").
trans-unit.target: You can find the correct port number on the Dashboard for the VM in the Management Portal (under "SSH Details").

trans-unit.source: Connect to the Linux virtual machine using ssh.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the Linux virtual machine using ssh.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to accept the fingerprint of the host's public key the first time you log in.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to accept the fingerprint of the host's public key the first time you log in.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) You may copy myPrivateKey.key to ~/.ssh/id_rsa so that your OpenSSH client can automatically pick this up without the use of the -i option.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) You may copy myPrivateKey.key to ~/.ssh/id_rsa so that your OpenSSH client can automatically pick this up without the use of the -i option.

trans-unit.source: Get OpenSSL on Windows
trans-unit.target: Get OpenSSL on Windows

trans-unit.source: There are a number of utilities that include a openssl for Windows.
trans-unit.target: There are a number of utilities that include a openssl for Windows.

trans-unit.source: A few examples are listed below -
trans-unit.target: A few examples are listed below -

trans-unit.source: Use Msysgit
trans-unit.target: Use Msysgit

trans-unit.source: Download and install msysgit from the following location: <link><linkText>http://msysgit.github.com/</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Download and install msysgit from the following location: <link><linkText>http://msysgit.github.com/</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Run msys from the installed directory (example: c:\msysgit\msys.exe)
trans-unit.target: Run msys from the installed directory (example: c:\msysgit\msys.exe)

trans-unit.source: Change to the bin directory by typing in cd bin
trans-unit.target: Change to the bin directory by typing in cd bin

trans-unit.source: Use GitHub for Windows
trans-unit.target: Use GitHub for Windows

trans-unit.source: Download and install GitHub for Windows from the following location: <link><linkText>http://windows.github.com/</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Download and install GitHub for Windows from the following location: <link><linkText>http://windows.github.com/</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Run Git Shell from the Start Menu > All Programs > GitHub, Inc
trans-unit.target: Run Git Shell from the Start Menu > All Programs > GitHub, Inc

trans-unit.source: Note: You may encounter the following error when running the openssl commands above:
trans-unit.target: Note: You may encounter the following error when running the openssl commands above:

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to resolve this is to set the OPENSSL_CONF environment variable.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to resolve this is to set the OPENSSL_CONF environment variable.

trans-unit.source: The process for setting this variable will vary depending on the shell that you have configured in Github:
trans-unit.target: The process for setting this variable will vary depending on the shell that you have configured in Github:

trans-unit.source: Powershell:
trans-unit.target: Powershell:

trans-unit.source: CMD:
trans-unit.target: CMD:

trans-unit.source: Git Bash:
trans-unit.target: Git Bash:

trans-unit.source: Use Cygwin
trans-unit.target: Use Cygwin

trans-unit.source: Download and install Cygwin from the following location: <link><linkText>http://cygwin.com/</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Download and install Cygwin from the following location: <link><linkText>http://cygwin.com/</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Ensure that the OpenSSL package and all of its dependencies are installed.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that the OpenSSL package and all of its dependencies are installed.

trans-unit.source: Run cygwin
trans-unit.target: Run cygwin

trans-unit.source: Create a Private Key on Windows
trans-unit.target: Create a Private Key on Windows

trans-unit.source: Follow one of the set of instructions above to be able to run openssl.exe
trans-unit.target: Follow one of the set of instructions above to be able to run openssl.exe

trans-unit.source: Type in the following command:
trans-unit.target: Type in the following command:

trans-unit.source: Your screen should look like the following:
trans-unit.target: Your screen should look like the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>linuxwelcomegit</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>linuxwelcomegit</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Answer the questions that are asked.
trans-unit.target: Answer the questions that are asked.

trans-unit.source: It would have created two files: myPrivateKey.key and myCert.pem.
trans-unit.target: It would have created two files: myPrivateKey.key and myCert.pem.

trans-unit.source: If you are going to use the API directly, and not use the Management Portal, convert the myCert.pem to myCert.cer (DER encoded X509 certificate) using the following command:
trans-unit.target: If you are going to use the API directly, and not use the Management Portal, convert the myCert.pem to myCert.cer (DER encoded X509 certificate) using the following command:

trans-unit.source: Create a PPK for Putty
trans-unit.target: Create a PPK for Putty

trans-unit.source: Download and install Puttygen from the following location: <link><linkText>http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Download and install Puttygen from the following location: <link><linkText>http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Puttygen may not be able to read the private key that was created earlier (myPrivateKey.key).
trans-unit.target: Puttygen may not be able to read the private key that was created earlier (myPrivateKey.key).

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to translate it into an RSA private key that Puttygen can understand:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to translate it into an RSA private key that Puttygen can understand:

trans-unit.source: The command above should produce a new private key called myPrivateKey_rsa.
trans-unit.target: The command above should produce a new private key called myPrivateKey_rsa.

trans-unit.source: Run puttygen.exe
trans-unit.target: Run puttygen.exe

trans-unit.source: Click the menu: File > Load a Private Key
trans-unit.target: Click the menu: File > Load a Private Key

trans-unit.source: Find your private key, which we named myPrivateKey_rsa above.
trans-unit.target: Find your private key, which we named myPrivateKey_rsa above.

trans-unit.source: You will need to change the file filter to show All Files (\*.\*)
trans-unit.target: You will need to change the file filter to show All Files (\*.\*)

trans-unit.source: Click Open.
trans-unit.target: Click Open.

trans-unit.source: You will receive a prompt which should look like this:
trans-unit.target: You will receive a prompt which should look like this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>linuxgoodforeignkey</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>linuxgoodforeignkey</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK
trans-unit.target: Click OK

trans-unit.source: Click Save Private Key, which is highlighted in the screenshot below:
trans-unit.target: Click Save Private Key, which is highlighted in the screenshot below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>linuxputtyprivatekey</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>linuxputtyprivatekey</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save the file as a PPK
trans-unit.target: Save the file as a PPK

trans-unit.source: Use Putty to Connect to a Linux Machine
trans-unit.target: Use Putty to Connect to a Linux Machine

trans-unit.source: Download and install putty from the following location: <link><linkText>http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Download and install putty from the following location: <link><linkText>http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Run putty.exe
trans-unit.target: Run putty.exe

trans-unit.source: Fill in the host name using the IP from the Management Portal:
trans-unit.target: Fill in the host name using the IP from the Management Portal:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>linuxputtyconfig</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>linuxputtyconfig</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Before selecting Open, click the Connection > SSH > Auth tab to choose your key.
trans-unit.target: Before selecting Open, click the Connection > SSH > Auth tab to choose your key.

trans-unit.source: See the screenshot below for the field to fill in:
trans-unit.target: See the screenshot below for the field to fill in:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>linuxputtyprivatekey</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>linuxputtyprivatekey</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Open to connect to your virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Click Open to connect to your virtual machine
